subject: Re: [junit] Re: Test Grouping/Partitioning
msgSnippet: @RunWith(Category.class) public class Nightly { } Would be a start--if we have a classpath scanner, that should be enough.  From there:
messageBody:
@RunWith(Category.class)
public class Nightly {
}

Would be a start--if we have a classpath scanner, that should be
enough. From there:

@RunWith(Category.class)
@ClassnameFilters({"mytests.*", ".*Test"})
public class Nightly {
@BeforeClass public void logStart() {
log("starting nightly build");
}
}

Not that the second would be possible necessarily right off the bat,
but it would be clearer how to do it than if the categories were
strings.

David Saff

On 7/12/07, Bradley, Todd <todd.bradley@...> wrote:
> > > As far as the categories go, I would like to see a simple
> > method-level
> > > annotation that looks like this:
> > >
> > > @TestGroups={"nightly", "quick", "bug"}
> >
> > Any takers on identifying categories with classes?
> >
> > @TestGroups({Nightly.class, Quick.class, Bug.class})
> >
> > I'm thinking:
> >
> > - auto-completion
> > - refactoring
> > - easy hook for running (just run Nightly.class to get the Nightly
> build)
> > - easy place for further customization (@BeforeClass, @AfterClass,
> etc)
>
> Those are definitely nice benefits. I'm having a hard time visualizing
> what Nightly.java is, though. A test suite which runs anything
> annotated with itself? An empty class?
>
>
> Todd.
